Medicare for All as we know it today was first introduced in Congress in 2003 by John Conyers. While it wasn’t popular at the time, today a majority of House Democrats are in support.
Even when Congress stopped pushing for Medicare for All in the Reagan era, activists began to fight harder than ever before for a health care system that covered everyone.

In the early 1970s, there were many plans for universal coverage, including from Ted Kennedy, but none of them gained enough traction. One of these plans from Republican Senator Jacob Javits would have expanded Medicare to cover everyone.
After decades of fighting special interests, proponents for universal healthcare settled on Medicare for seniors which passed in 1965 and was widely popular and expanded in the following decade.
After World War II, Harry Truman came out in support but once again the opposition stood in his way by framing it as socialized medicine during the Cold War. (sound familiar?)

The ideas behind Medicare for All became popular in the early 1900s and were broadly supported by unions and workers — but opposed by businesses and doctors. FDR wanted to add health coverage to the Social Security Act in 1935 but was stopped due to this opposition.
Those who claim that Medicare for All is unrealistic, expensive, and not popular with the American people need to read up on their history.

Corey’s story can happen to anyone who needs healthcare in America. With Medicare for All, his family wouldn’t have to deal with co-pays, deductibles, premiums & high costs for prescription drugs. No more out of network costs or being forced to switch doctors & specialists.
Corey still hasn’t seen a dentist in six years. Under Medicare for All he would finally be able to get the dental care he needs.

After completing the two year waiting period for Medicare eligibility, Corey started receiving the Disabled Adult Child benefit from SSA and Medicare along with Medicaid. He has had a much better experience as most of what he needs is covered.
As Corey’s home health provider, his mom is self-employed through Medicaid, so getting insurance would be astronomical in cost. This caused Corey’s physical and mental health to suffer.

Corey’s dad had an accident and was permanently disabled in 2014 which resulted in his retirement. This August, his dad lost his employer-provided coverage because his Long Term disability expired which also covered his mom.

Corey had to stop physical therapy when his insurance decided to no longer cover it. Private insurance also wouldn’t cover any of the medical equipment including wheelchairs and special urinals. His family couldn’t afford to pay for them out of pocket.

While growing up, Corey had to switch doctors and specialists frequently due to them being out of network when his Dad’s employer switched insurance providers. Ever since, his family & doctors have had to fight insurance companies so he could continue receiving necessary care.

Corey lives in Des Moines, IA and was born with Cerebral Palsy affecting his right side. When Corey was growing up, his father had excellent insurance. Because he is unable to be gainfully employed, receiving the healthcare he needs has been a journey from day one.

Obviously I find appalling China’s human rights abuses. I believe in American exceptionalism and that our free enterprise democracy is better than China’s authoritarian capitalism. My point was that instead of bad wars we should be investing in infrastructure, energy & education!
We are at heart a nation based on philosophical ideals, not blood. The American scriptures are the Constitution, the Declaration of Independence, Dr. King’s writings..

One can condemn China’s massive human rights violations and still believe that we shouldn’t allow them to build a strategic advantage in infrastructure and education investment. And that we should invest in our homeland instead of wasting trillions on bad wars!
I obviously condemn China’s human rights abuses and believe our free enterprise democracy is a better system. I was simply paraphrasing a call between Trump and Carter.

I was just paraphrasing a phone conversation between Trump and Carter which Trump praised and where Carter made these points. https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2019/04/16/trump-chats-jimmy-carter-china-claims-he-always-like-him/3483656002/

My point is instead of investing trillions in wars we should be investing in science, technology, education here at home. We need to have a sputnik like mentality to make sure our system of government remains the model for the world.

I like your writing on realclear politics. I just want to be clear. I believe American democracy and free enterprise is much better than China’s authoritarian capitalism. But China has not been in endless wars and is making investments in critical technologies and infrastructure.

In SV, we have a saying: Only the paranoid survive. @FrankLuntz I rather we not underestimate the Chinese. We both believe in the exceptionalism of American values. Let’s find common cause on stopping bad wars and making the investments necessary so America wins the 21st century.

I am not arguing for anything knew. It’s the Hamiltonian view that propelled America into a world power. It’s Lincoln with Land Grant Universities. It’s our Sputnik mentality that led to so much of the technology in my district in Silicon Valley.

But we need as Americans to find a common purpose and make the investments we need to succeed in a technology revolution. My only point is that infrastructure, broadband, NSF, NIH, DARPA, clean energy, education should be seen as bipartisan priorities to win the 21st century.

Agree @FrankLuntz. That’s what is concerning. We know we can beat fascism and communism. But we have never been tested by authoritarian capitalism (China’s system). I would much rather live in our messy democracy that values rights and freedoms...

5/5 Final point. I actually enjoying your commentary @FrankLuntz even when we disagree. You are smart to talk about economic freedom instead of a type of capitalism that privileges the rich and connected. I welcome a longer conversation!

4/4 This point was not even an attack on Trump. It was more a sense of what we as Americans must do to make sure that free enterprise democracy prevails and not China’s authoritarian capitalism with censorship. On this issue, @FrankLuntz all Americans should be on the same team.

3/3 We didn’t win the Cold War by complacency. We were fueled by Sputnik. We shouldn’t seek a new Cold War with China. But we should make sure we are investing in the critical technology and infrastructure to win in the 21st century.

2/2 They haven’t engaged in military interventionism. If they are our primary competition, we should make sure we outcompete them in infrastructure, artificial intelligence, green energy, education. My point was simply that we should end bad wars and invest in our people!

1/1) I appreciate the back and forth. I am not elevating them in anyway. My concern is that China doesn’t win the 21st century with authoritarian capitalism. Our values are better. But they are being strategic in their investments. We can’t be complacent...
